awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigating the structure and dynamics of proton defects in heterogeneous environments with accelerated quantum simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Thomas Markland of Stanford University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to develop techniques to speed up molecular simulations.   The particular focus is on transport of protons in complex environments. These simulations include the quantum mechanical nature of the electrons and nuclei that make up the atoms in a molecule.  Markland's approach allows for making and breaking chemical bonds as the simulation progresses, which is essential for understanding the transport and chemical reactivity of light atoms such as protons. Proton transport processes in disordered systems are of fundamental importance in systems ranging from chemistry and materials science to geology and biology. These include the elucidation of transport mechanisms in proton exchange membranes used in fuel cells and in biological proton channels, providing insights into their functionality, and how to tune these materials for high efficiency proton transport. Professor Markland is also developing simulation and visualization experiences to improve high school education as well as to encourage more students to study chemistry by hosting high school teachers in his lab. These simulation and visualization experiences aid teachers in implementing scientific exercises that engage students' interest and stimulate them to inquire about the natural world. This is being achieved via partnership with several Stanford outreach programs. 

This research is aimed at understanding of the structure and dynamics of proton defects in heterogeneous environments, in concert with the development of approaches to accelerate ab initio path integral molecular dynamics simulations. These methods exploit time- and length-scale separation approaches to increase the efficiency of these simulations based on ring polymer contraction and multiple time-scale molecular dynamics algorithms.  Markland and his research group use these approaches to investigate the interplay of structure and dynamics in a wide range of heterogeneous systems containing proton defects ranging from hydrophobic and hydrophilic interfaces to nanoporous systems. These studies are being used to understand how the chemical environment can be tailored to change the transport and reactivity of proton defects

por.por_cntn:
This award developed new theoretical and simulation approaches to efficiently model transport and spectroscopy of proton defects in aqueous and enzymatic systems based on multiple timescale ab initio molecular dynamics, machine learning and path integral quantum mechanics approaches. Being able to accurately simulate these systems is essential to understand processes that underpin the design of new materials and understand biological mechanisms. This work provided a number of methodological improvements combined with applications to condensed phase proton transport systems as well as methods to extract, decompose and understand the origins of experimental observables using simulations. The achievements of this research were to make it more tractable to perform simulations incorporating the quantum mechanical nature of both the nuclei and electrons to study the interplay of hydrogen bond dynamics and the transport of reactive proton defects (proton and hydroxide) in chemical environments ranging from liquid water to ionic solutions and enzymes. Since proton defect transport in these systems involves a structural diffusion mechanism involving light atoms it is important to treat them using simulations that allow for bond making and breaking as well as nuclear quantum effects, such as zero-point energy and tunneling. Techniques such as path integral molecular dynamics, centroid molecular dynamics and ring polymer molecular dynamics when combined with an ab initio treatment of the electronic structure (traditionally at the DFT level) allow for the incorporation of these effects. However, for condensed phase systems where system sizes of at least 300-500 atoms are needed for nanosecond timescales these simulations have been traditionally limited to 10’s of picoseconds rather than the nanosecond or longer timescales required to converge transport properties and spectra. In the first part of this award, we thus demonstrated that by combining ab initio multiple timestepping techniques with our ab initio ring polymer contraction approach one can obtain a computational speed-up of two orders of magnitude in performing ab initio path integral molecular dynamics (AI-PIMD) simulations and used this to enable AIMD and AI-PIMD simulations into the nanoseconds for proton containing systems. This award also led to new methods to decompose the molecular quantum kinetic energy tensor obtained from path integral simulations into easily physically interpretable components to allow the elucidation of isotope effects in ionic solution. We also provided methods to separate linear and non-linear infra-red and vibrational spectroscopies performed in solution into contributions arising from particular underlying atomic motions and solvation environments as well as showing how rate theories based on transition state theory and a Marcus theory like picture can be used to extract insights into the nature of proton transport in acid solutions at a range of concentrations. In addition, this award led to insights into electric fields, as probed by Stark spectroscopy, and electronic charge transfer effects observed in ionic solutions and enzymes and the role of nuclear quantum effects in enhancing electronic charge transfer.

 As part of this award, we also introduced approaches to allow ground and photoinduced electron and hole transfer diabatic states and their couplings to be obtained from density functional theory calculations. These approaches are able to give accuracies comparable to computationally costly methods at a cost orders of magnitude less and with better scalings to allow them to be applied to much larger systems where excited state electron and hole transfer are important ranging from exciton dissociation at photovoltaic heterojunctions, photoinduced charge transfer at electrodes, and electron transfer in photosynthetic reaction centers. To extend our ability to treat larger systems incorporating reactive proton defects or those requiring longer simulation timescales, such as is required such as at disordered interfaces (liquid-vapor or a solid surface) we have used our existing ab initio simulations to provide accurate machine learned potentials trained on ab initio data to describe the properties of water.

As part of the broader impact of this grant the PI hosted a high school teacher in his lab for the summer. The high school teacher developed simulation and visualization experiences based around scientific exercises to engage students’ interest and stimulate them to inquire about the natural world. This led to the development of new lesson plans incorporating simulations that are were taught at Bay Area schools.
